abstract.p: When measuring with an atomic force microscope (AFM), the probe would move to the prescribed position via the platform and its vibration would occur. To achieve precision positioning for the follow-up scanning and high-speed measurement, in this paper, mathematical modeling and control of the probe is focused to avoid the damage incurred by the collision between the probe and the sample and to obtain the high measurement in the scanning step. The Hamilton’s principle is firstly employed to derive the equation of motion and its boundary conditions. Next, the summation method, Lagrangian equation and Laplace transform are applied to obtain natural frequencies, a dynamic model of the AFM probe, and to work out the transfer function of the open-loop system. The proposed model is compared with two conventional AFM probe models: point–mass model and conventional cantilever beam model - where one of the ends of the cantilever and basic platform are assumed to be fixed. Finally, collocated control is exercised to designate the positions for actuator and sensor and the root locus method cooperated with proportional-integral-derivative controllers to simulate the performance of the control system. The result shows that the controller can ensure the stability of this continuous system and perform effective control.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The mainstream new technology in the 21st century covers bio-gene, network technology and miniature, one of which is nanotechnology - a rising favorite in the fields of technology and industry. In recent years, the atomic force microscope (AFM) has been gaining popularity among the nanometer-related fields. Especially, in terms of nanometer bio-medicine and bio-chemical technology, AFM has been widely applied to resolve many riddles that seemed beyond human reach. It is mainly because AFM can provide a higher resolution rate to facilitate the discovery of the interaction between many nano-scale molecules or atoms and surface phenomena. The AFM probe is composed of a cantilever beam whose ingredient is Si or Si3 N4 and a tip which ranges from 10 to 100 nm in diameter. Its principle is to use the interactive force between the tip and sample to make the beam deflect or be slightly displaced. Laser reflection principle is used to detect the displacement of the probe. If scanned, the displacement would be imaged. This is what we call the imaging principle of AFM.

In 1982 Binning et al. (1982) at the IBM lab in Zurich developed the first nanometer surface analysis instrument: scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). Its principle is to use the change in tunnel electricity between the probe and sample. The increasing feasibility of controlling material under the nanometer size can support fabricating material, component and device from top to bottom. Invented by Binning et al. (1986) in 1985, AFM was with the atom resolution, which can be used for surface inspection on multiple materials. Additionally it can be operated in a vacuum, a gas or liquid environment. Jianhua et al. (2005) characterized the thermo-mechanical responses of an arbitrarily shaped AFM cantilever in measuring mechanical properties of biological specimens. Because biological cells and macromolecules are usually highly compliant, an ultra-low level of forces must be applied using extremely soft cantilevers and monitoring deformations in response to controlled applied forces in order not to damage their structure. Yabuno et al. (2008) focused on non-contact atomic force microscopy in a liquid environment. The self-exciting technique for the micro cantilever probe has been introduced to maintain steady state amplitude and prevent damage to the sample surface. Compared to other nano-lithography, such as electron-beam lithography and X-ray lithography, AFM is cheaper and quite suitable for research on nanotechnology.

When the traditional AFM is employed for measurement, the waiting time is comparatively long. Despite the fact that most AFMs are equipped with a vibration-free table to shield the external vibration disturbance, the probe itself is flexible and vibration and the interaction with samples would happen in actuation. In addition, vibration control of the micro-cantilever in nanomanipulation using AFM is needed. This improves the manipulability of the AFM. Therefore, for achieving high-speed measurement and precision positioning to conduct the follow-up image scanning, a deep analysis of the probe’s dynamic performances is necessary.

sec.title: label>2. Research objective
sec.p: AFM is a kind of tool operating under the nanometer. Although it can be explained by the special feature and theory of the beam, the effect exerted by the interaction force over tip should be considered. Holscher et al. (1999) simulated a probe by concentrating mass and employed a perturbation method to study natural frequency.

Ricardo and Ruben (2002) utilized non-contact AFM and gave a cosine wave of impacting force to basic platform and sample substrate. In order to discuss the image of interaction force between atoms and the lateral force on the tip measuring, Chang and Chu (2003) expressed a sample in terms of spring to figure out the resolution to natural frequency. Ashhab et al. (1999) and Basso et al. (1998) expressed a probe with the physical model of lumped parameters. Jalili et al. (2004) investigated the microcantilever-sample interaction in non-contact mode of AFM using the general distributed – parameters base modeling approach. Metin and Hideki (2000) employed contact AFM and replaced the basic platform, tip and sample with damping and spring, giving consideration to the change in the relationship between van der Waals’ forces, capillary forces, electrostatic forces and the repulsive contact forces, and to study the end displacement and change in natural frequency. Until recently more efforts have been made to study the effect of the tip shape and tensile strength over the high precision and density of the probe (Gibson et al., 2004; Yamanaka et al., 1999).
The mechanical vibrations of the micro-cantilever restrict the resolution of AFM.

Most studies in dynamic analysis and vibration control of the AFM cantilever have been proposed. The mathematic model of cantilever beam with tip mass is usually obtained based on Euler-Bernoulli theory, Halmilton’s principle and Lagrange equations (Dadfarnia et al., 2004; Samir, 2010; Yim and Singh, 2003). The sensitivity of vibration modes of atomic force microscope cantilevers are taken into consideration for the high-resolution image of surfaces. The result showed each vibration mode has a different sensitivity to variations in surface stiffness (Chang, 2002; Joseph and Joshua, 2001). In view of this, it is of paramount importance to establish a complete mathematical model which serves as the basis for designing controller. However, higher vibration modes have usually been ignored in particular conditions. Truncating high frequency often turns the minimal phase characteristic into a non-minimal phase characteristic, thus causing control and measurement to overshoot in the real system, and furthermore, higher modes offer lower thermal noise, higher quality factors, and higher sensitivity to stiff samples. Ignoring such properties could distort or affect the accuracy of measurements (Arafat et al., 2008; Sugimoto et al., 2007). Further, for the reason of reducing analytical complexity, most researches concentrated on the first two or three vibration modes of the dynamic model of micro-cantilever in analysis (Ashhab et al., 1999; Cunningham et al., 1995; Wenming et al., 2006). Generally speaking, in establishing the mathematical model of the continuous system in the literature, only the first few low frequency modes are usually considered to represent the whole motion model of the system. In contrast, this paper provided the method on dynamic analysis and vibration control of the micro-cantilever beam in arbitrarily resonance frequency, which made it applicable to a wide diversity of nano-electromechanical systems.

sec.title: 4. Simulation result and discussion
sec.p: Stability, accuracy and promptness are usually very important subjects in a feedback control system. The performance indices are designed through a standard second order system. The paper attempts to employ the system’s first mode to firstly design the parameter range for controller and then return to the high order system for fine-tuning. Nevertheless, industrial engineers usually rely on experience to follow a trial-and-error method when adjusting PID parameters, which determines that it is inconvenient and time-consuming to make necessary readjustment after changing the parameters of the controlled system.
The most direct way to study the performance of the system operation is to input the standard input signal as the reference input and then analyze the diagram for a time response of the system.

We performed simulations to compare the differential of the proposed model and the point-mass model and the conventional cantilever models presented in the previous section based on the natural frequencies (NF). The parameters of the AFM probe are presented in Table 1. The simulation results are shown in Tables 2 and 3. Table 2 shows the NF of the models in absent interaction force and Table 3 indicates the NF of the models when the tip is affected by the interaction forces. Firstly, it is easy to see that the point-mass model only described the first mode NF of the AFM probe, while other models gave the higher modes of the AFM probe system. Furthermore, the NF of the first mode of point-mass model is different from the NF of the first mode of the cantilever model. A next simple simulation is carried out to analyze this difference and the result is shown in Figure 7. The difference caused by the assumption that the deformation of cantilever looks like the deformation of the spring so this assumption is suitable when the ratio mass of tip to mass of the cantilever is high. However the ratio of mass tip to mass of cantilever is only from 1.5% to under 10%. Hence, the point-mass model cannot give NF of high modes of the AFM and the obtained NF of the first mode is also not accurate to describe the structure of the AFM microscope. Secondly, Tables 2 and 3 also show that the conventional cantilever model is to remove the rigid body mode of the AFM probe (the effective of z scanner mass). The proposed model shows the effect of the z scanner mass on the structure of the AFM probe. Moreover, in Table 2, the different NF of modes of introduced models were small in absent interaction forces. However, Table 3 indicates that there are significantly various and different NF of modes of models when the tip of probe is affected by the interaction force. So these various and different NF of models influence the quality of the control and scan the image of the sample surface. Two small simulations are carried out to investigate the effect of the mass of the Z scanner and the Young modulus of the sample surface to the dynamic structure of AFM probe by considering the convert of NF. Figure 8(a) shows the mass of the basic platform affected direct to the NF of the rigid body mode while Figure 8(b) indicates that the properties of sample surface significantly influenced the four first modes of the AFM probe. Finally, simulation is carried out to investigate the tracking ability of the PD and PID controller based on (105) and (111). Figure 9 and Figure 10 show that the controller can track the shape of the sample surface with high speed scanning. The resultant simulation and analyses prove that the proposed model describes the dynamic structure of the AFM probe more accurately and the controller guarantees the system stability and the expected goals. sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p:
The research developed an improved model and a control strategy for the motion control of an AFM probe measurement system. High-speed and high-precision motion control of an AFM probe measurement system with flexible modes is naturally more complex and difficult than the motion control of those with conventional rigid probe. The research activities involve modeling, analysis, and simulation. Besides, the effectiveness of the mass tip and the various properties of the sample can be investigated. A computationally efficient control algorithm with guaranteed stability is developed, and the control and observation spillovers are not present. The paper finally comes up with the following conclusions:
In accordance with the system simulation diagram, the transient response in the motion of the probe can firstly be observed. After figuring out the kinetic energy and the potential energy, the Hamilton’s principle is used to derive the partial differential equations of motion and the boundary conditions. The following application of Lagrangian equations and Laplace transform and mode summation method would yield the transfer function of the open-loop system, which ensures that infinite poles and zeros of the system can be calculated so as to effectively design a controller. The proposed model is compared with the point-mass model and conventional cantilever model.
By means of the mode summation method, the probe’s distributed parameter can be transformed into infinite simultaneous second order ordinary differential equations and the NF of the system can be found. The poles of the open-loop transfer function can be obtained, and the reliable mode number can be selected for simulation analysis.
When the first mode is designed and other modes are located over the left half plane of the s-domain, the system would reach stability. Additionally, the standard second order system is employed to set the design range and rule of the parameters, the designed controller’s parameters can live up to the expected goal and the probe can operate stably and precisely positioned under the nanometer unit.
